title: Andrei Kolesnikov: 'There is a civil society in Russia that is trying to resist'
summary: The political scientist and columnist at 'Novaya Gazeta' considers that while some Russians 'opposed to the Kremlin and its war, which is not theirs' have chosen exile, 'the bravest have remained in Russia.'

title: EU-Mercosur: Why the French have opposed this free trade agreement
summary: The French government wants to block the free trade agreement between the European Union and five South American countries. Meanwhile, farmers have called for nationwide protests starting on Monday.

title: Mamadou Diouf: 'Imperial history can no longer be articulated exclusively by France'
summary: The president of the commemoration committee for the Thiaroye massacre in Senegal believes that African countries must regain control of their historical narrative, and is calling on France to return all its archives.

title: War in Lebanon: Children go back to public schools, despite fear of bombardment
summary: Over 200,000 primary and secondary public schoolchildren have gone back to school, whether face-to-face or online. Teachers have been left to their own devices, organizing their classes against a backdrop of war.

title: France beat All Blacks 30-29, securing third-straight win
summary: France trailed early and at half-time before managing to turn the tide in a thrilling second half. Beating New Zealand three consecutives times has only happened twice before, in 1994 and 1995.

title: G7 calls Russia the sole obstacle to 'just and lasting peace' in Ukraine
summary: In a joint statement, the G7 states also stated their 'unwavering support for Ukraine for as long as it takes.' Meanwhile, Ukraine's Volodymyr Zelensky said Kyiv would like a diplomatic end to the war next year.

title: How pro-Trump conservatives built up an alternative media ecosystem through podcasts
summary: Their names are Joe Rogan, Charlie Kirk and Andrew Schulz: In recent months, their conservative podcasts − which have millions of listeners in the US − all hosted Donald Trump and promoted his ideas.

title: China: Deadly knife attack in vocational school
summary: The deadly stabbing attack, which has killed 8 and left 17 wounded, was committed in the eastern Chinese city of Yixing. A suspect, whom police claimed has confessed, has been arrested.

title: Amid the war in Ukraine, the delicate task of appointing a French ambassador to Russia
summary: After much uncertainty, Nicolas de Rivière, the current French representative to the United Nations, has been appointed ambassador to Moscow. However, as is customary, Russia must now grant its approval.

title: Tens of thousands flee as Typhoon Man-yi nears Philippines
summary: Man-yi will be the sixth major storm to pound the Philippines in the past month. At least 163 people have died so far from the storms, which have left thousands homeless and have wiped out the country's crops and livestock.

title: How America's tech right came to power
summary: The role of several Silicon Valley billionaires in Donald Trump's re-election as US president, most notably Elon Musk highlights the influence of a new ideological current bridging libertarian utopias and conservative values.

title: Social services in Sweden could force some young people to wear ankle tags
summary: The right and far right majority want to authorize social services to take coercive measures to prevent the recruitment of minors by gangs and to combat organized crime.

title: Zelensky says Ukraine war will end 'sooner' with Trump in office
summary: The Ukrainian president said he had a 'constructive exchange' with Trump during their telephone conversation after his US presidential election victory.

title: The 'visceral' anguish of France's Lebanese community
summary: Since the escalation between Israel and Hezbollah at the end of September, the Lebanese community in France (between 50,000 and 60,000 people) has been keeping a close eye on the media relaying news from the region and sticking together.

title: In Paris, former artists' studios will soon be turned into large tourist apartments
summary: In a historic alleyway in the 14th arrondissement, residents fear their neighborhood will be transformed into a 'bachelor party location.'

title: Democratic states prepare to be on front line against Trump's policies
summary: In the absence of a counterweight in Congress, blue states are trying, as they did in 2016, to organize themselves. This time, however, they are not benefiting from popular mobilization.

title: COP29: From aviation to the super-rich, the search for innovative climate financing
summary: To mobilize the huge sums needed to finance ecological transition and adapt to global warming, several countries, including France, are considering new global taxes.

title: In Iran, the suicide of opposition figure Kianoosh Sanjari sends shockwaves through social media
summary: Imprisoned and forcibly confined to psychiatric hospitals several times, Sanjari, a human rights activist, blogger and journalist took his own life on Wednesday 'in protest against the dictatorship of Khamenei.'

title: Trump chooses oil executive Chris Wright as energy secretary
summary: The head of Liberty Energy is expected to fulfill the president-elect's campaign promise to 'drill, baby, drill" and increase fossil fuel production.

title: Olaf Scholz reconnects with Vladimir Putin, angering Ukraine
summary: The German chancellor spoke to the Russian president over the phone on Friday. This call follows another between Trump and Putin, and although it stems from domestic political concerns, it has upset Kyiv.

title: The emotional burden of older sisters: 'I'm strong, I prefer to suffer for others'
summary: As first-born siblings, some girls feel they have a duty to listen to and care for their younger siblings. This role, also nourished by literary and cinematic representations, is by no means inevitable and can be reinvented in adulthood.

title: Thirty-five years after the fall of the wall, liberal Berlin has lost its luster
summary: The embodiment of the Germany that benefited so much from the open, liberal world after the fall of the Iron Curtain in 1989, the 'capital of cool,' which is now attracting start-ups and seeing its rents soar, is suffering from the crisis of its model.

title: Dutch government narrowly avoids crisis after violent incidents in Amsterdam
summary: A state secretary has resigned, denouncing the racist remarks of some of her colleagues. Prime Minister Dick Schoof denies this and is trying to convince people that his government has a future.

title: Israel pummels southern Beirut, 'heavy rocket barrage' on Haifa
summary: According to Lebanese state media, Israeli ground forces reached the deepest point in Lebanon since the invasion on October 1.

title: Super Typhoon Man-yi makes landfall in Philippines, sixth storm in one month
summary: Authorities have not reported any casualties from the storm, which packed winds up to 260 kilometers per hour.

title: Sweden's new doting dads
summary: Sweden allows 480 days of parental leave to be shared between parents. Fathers are happy to take it, saying it helps them bond with their children.

title: France's gold rush 2.0
summary: Gold prices have doubled in five years, a surge that attracts many French people looking to make ends meet or help their loved ones. But this frenzy also attracts the greed of crooks.

title: Russia launches large-scale strikes on Ukraine's energy infrastructure
summary: The wave of attacks made use of some 120 missiles and 90 drones, according to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. It has led to power cuts in the Kyiv, Donetsk, and Dnipropetrovsk regions, as well as civilian casualties across the country.

title: A Florida retirement home throws a party. Does anyone care?
summary: Gathered in a Florida parking lot on November 9, Donald Trump supporters celebrated his victory in full American style.

title: Far-right fake jobs trial: Marine Le Pen's malign offensive
summary: The far-right leader is trying to turn the trial about her party's MEP assistants into a political affair. Having regularly denounced judicial leniency, her and her party's leaders' challenge to legal rigor is inappropriate when they themselves are implicated.

title: Bondage for all: 'In Paris, you can choose between three or four BDSM parties every weekend'
summary: In bed with the French, part 5: Bondage has emerged from the shadows and is now being taught in playful workshops. These days it's more about consent-centred eroticism than debauchery.

title: Anti-vax conspiracy theorist and JFK's nephew: Who is Robert F. Kennedy Jr.?
summary: Known for his vaccine skepticism, John F. Kennedy's nephew has been nominated by Donald Trump as health secretary. His first mission is to take on big pharmaceutical companies and food and drug regulatory agencies.

title: Michigan's Donald Trump voters: A tale of collective amnesia
summary: Ever-increasing numbers of blue-collar workers, Latinos, Muslims and African-Americans voted for Donald Trump, swinging the Midwest state for him. All seemed to have forgotten his harsh behavior, and sometimes even insults, toward them.

title: Three easy Lebanese recipes
summary: Tuesday is veggie day! Roasted cauliflower with pomegranate; lentil, chard and potato soup; and orange blossom pudding: Made with a little spice and a lot of love, Lebanese cuisine is all about simplicity and generosity.

title: Anti-cyclist discontent is on the rise in France: 'They don't respect anything!'
summary: On urban cycle paths, cohabitation between fatbikes, electric unicycles, cargo bikes and scooters is proving difficult. 'Bicycle bashing' is becoming a growing sentiment, with cyclists being accused of reckless and selfish behavior.
